The main goal of this app is to be a search tool for Quechua language vocabulary. For this, it lets you search in multiple dictionaries at once. Nonetheless, this app is not a translation app.

Your results will depend on some factors like: 
	a) The ortograph you use, 
	b) Using simple words or word roots instead of complex sentences, 
	c) the availability of words in the dictionaries. 

You can also try the search type "contains" in order to get more results
I\'ve searched for a \"simple\" word, but got no results.

While searching from Quechua, bear in mind that because of Quechua\'s agglutinative nature, what may seem like a simple word could actually be a root + multiple suffixes. \nFor instance, while searching for \"wasiykita\" we may probably get no results. Our advice would be to try to use the word root (usually the first two syllabes) while using the "Starts with" search type. That way, we would rather search for \"wasi\".

• Quechua language is written with 3 vowels (A, I, U). Some dictionaries use 5 vowels like in Spanish, so this app tries to adapt your search term to work the same whether you search for "qillu" or "qello", for example. Anyway, in this case, it's advisable to write "qillu". 

• Use the letter K instead of C or QUE/QUI. For example, you should write "karu" instead of "caru" and "killa" instead of "quilla". The letter that represents the /k/ sound is always the letter K. 

• Quechua letter H is not muted as in Spanish, but it is pronounced aspirated. 

• Writing with "cc" corresponds to an old way of writing Quechua. Even though many people still use this way of writing, it's advisable to use Q instead of CC, unless you want to search in ancient dictionaries (like Holguín's). 

• The letters Z and C are not used in Quechua, but letter S. We should write "isku" instead of "izku", "sisariy" instead of "sizariy". 

• There are no consecutive vowels like AI, AU, IA, UA, UI, IU. In order to avoid this, semiconsonants Y and W are used. This way, we must write AY, AW, YA, WA, WI, IW.
You can watch and learn more about Quechua writing on our YouTube channel.
